holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence granted exclusive right to prospect, mine, and remove/appropriate up to 100 tons Bauxite, constituting realisation of part of capital asset (Bauxite deposits) akin to salami payments, not mere user of land; Tribunal/High Court mischaracterised nature of grant

holdings.text: the transaction was not one merely of the user of capital assets but of their realisation, By this test therefore the receipts were on capital account and not revenue

anchor.surface_text: the transaction was not one merely of the user of capital assets but of their realisation, By this test therefore the receipts were on capital account and not revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence terms allow licensee to remove and appropriate Bauxite samples up to 100 tons aggregate, parting with portion of capital (minerals), applying user vs realisation test from precedents like Greyhounds

holdings.text: It cannot be said that this amounts merely to a grant of the use of the capital of the licensor but it was really a grant of a right to a portion of the capital in the shape of a general right to the capital asset

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said that this amounts merely to a grant of the use of the capital of the licensor but it was really a grant of a right to a portion of the capital in the shape of a general right to the capital asset.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit licence rights to enter, prospect, mine, bore, dig, and remove/appropriate up to 100 tons Bauxite constitute grant enabling realisation of minerals as capital, rejecting respondent's mere user contention

holdings.text: the observations above quoted were not based on this consideration but on the nature of the right which was conveyed

anchor.surface_text: but the observations above quoted were not based on this consideration but on the nature of the right which was conveyed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Kamakshya Narain Singh case: Privy Council holding on salami as capital not dependent on 999-year lease duration but on nature of right acquired (enjoyment benefits of lease)

holdings.text: there was a transfer of the right the consideration for which would be a capital payment

anchor.surface_text: and therefore there was a transfer of the right the consideration for which would be a capital payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Licence covenants confer right to enter land and take away/appropriate up to 100 tons Bauxite of every kind, effecting transfer of rights akin to capital realisation

precedents.citation: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1 1943 , L.R. 70 I.A. 186

anchor.surface_text: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1 the payments by way of premium were held to be capital receipts. In that case large payments by way of royalty for granting various mining leases were received by the assessee.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh of Ramgarh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: payments by way of premium or salami for mining leases are capital receipts
precedents.cited_holding: The salami, has been, rightly in their Lordships opinion, treated as a capital receipt. It is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessees to enjoy the benefits granted to them by the lease.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa v. Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh 1 1946 14 I.T.R. 738

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa v. Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh 1 a coal company had been given by the Court of Wards a prospecting licence in respect of certain coal bearing lands with the option of renewal and also to take a mining lease on certain terms and conditions.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa v. Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: salami received for prospecting licences and mining leases is a capital receipt
precedents.cited_holding: salami was a lump sum payment for rights which were being given to the licensee, namely, the right to prospect for a certain number of years and also the right to get mining leases and therefore salami in question was undoubtedly a capital receipt.

precedents.citation: The Province of Bihar v. Maharaja Pratap Udai Nath Sahi Deo of Ratugarh 2 1941 9 I.T.R. 313

anchor.surface_text: The Province of Bihar v. Maharaja Pratap Udai Nath Sahi Deo of Ratugarh 2 it was contended that payments in the nature of premium or salami were not part of the income of the assessee and were therefore not taxable

precedents.case_name: Province of Bihar v. Maharaja Pratap Udai Nath Sahi Deo of Ratugarh
precedents.cited_proposition: prima facie salami is not income; it may be rent in advance or capital
precedents.cited_holding: salami may, in certain cases, be regarded as a payment of rent in advance and it would in those cases be regarded as income but where it could not be so regarded it would not be income and therefore not taxable. It was also held that prima facie salami is not income.

precedents.citation: The Member for the Board of Agricultural Income Tax, Assam v. Smt. Sindurani Chaudhurani 1 1957 S.C.R. 1019

anchor.surface_text: The Member for the Board of Agricultural Income Tax, Assam v. Smt. Sindurani Chaudhurani 1 this Court defined salami as follows The indicia of salami are 1 its single non-recurring character and 2 payment prior to the creation of the tenancy.

precedents.case_name: Member for the Board of Agricultural Income Tax, Assam v. Smt. Sindurani Chaudhurani
precedents.cited_proposition: salami is a single non-recurring payment prior to creation of tenancy, consideration for being let into possession, capital receipt
precedents.cited_holding: It is the consideration paid by the tenant for being let into possession and can be neither rent nor revenue but is a capital receipt in the hands of the landlord.

precedents.citation: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singhs case 2 1943 L.R. 70 I.A. 180

anchor.surface_text: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singhs case 2 also the Privy Council laid the definition of salami in general terms and described the characteristics of a payment by way of salami without any reference to the nature of the lease.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bahadur Kamakshya Narain Singh case
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of salami laid in general terms without reference to nature of lease

anchor.surface_text: Lawrence, J., in Greyhounds case 3 The question as to what receipts are revenue and what are capital has given rise to much difference of opinion but it is clear, in my opinion, that, if the sum in question is received for what is in truth the user of capital assets and not for their realisation, it is a revenue receipt, not capital.

precedents.cited_proposition: receipts for user of capital assets (not realisation) are revenue
precedents.cited_holding: if the sum in question is received for what is in truth the user of capital assets and not for their realisation, it is a revenue receipt, not capital.

precedents.citation: R. B. P. Bannerji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 2 1951 19 I.T.R. 596

anchor.surface_text: R. B. P. Bannerji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 2 where it was held that compensation received by the assessee for use by the military of his lands for a short period was a revenue receipt.

precedents.case_name: R. B. P. Bannerji v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation for short-term use of land by military is revenue receipt

anchor.surface_text: Smethurst v. Davy 1 . That was a case which was decided on the wording of s. 31(1)(d) of the Finance Act of 1948, and therefore is not of much assistance.

precedents.citation: Stow Bardolph Gravel Co., Ltd. v. Poole 2 1954 35 T.C. 459

anchor.surface_text: Stow Bardolph Gravel Co., Ltd. v. Poole 2 . There the assessee company, which carried on business in sand and gravel, purchased two un worked deposits.

precedents.case_name: Stow Bardolph Gravel Co., Ltd. v. Poole
precedents.cited_proposition: payments to acquire unworked deposits are capital not trading stock

precedents.citation: Rajah Nanyam Meenakshamma v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 3 1956 30 I.T.R. 286

anchor.surface_text: Rajah Nanyam Meenakshamma v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad 3 . In that case certain fixed sums of money were paid as royalty for the whole period of the lease which were held to be revenue receipts as consolidated advance payments of the amount which would otherwise have been payable periodically.

precedents.case_name: Rajah Nanyam Meenakshamma v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: fixed sums paid as royalty for whole lease period are revenue as advance royalty
